indicators.justification:
Nature Protection Board of Latvia has developed a Nature Data Management System "OZOLS" (1). The system stores textual and geospatial information on specially protected species and habitats, nature reserves, and other information related to nature protection. For registered users, the information is available in open data, free of charge. Non-registered users (guests) can access the information in an interactive online map and an online display of the filtered information. According to Section 3 of the Cabinet of Ministers Regulation "Procedures for maintenance of the data management system, updating of data and circulation of information" (2) the rights of a registered user shall be granted to state and local government institutions and capital companies, certified experts in the field of protection of species and habitats, as well as natural and legal persons who carry out research or implement projects in the field of nature protection. The registration process takes up to 10 days.  

(1) Nature Data Management System "OZOLS", https://ozols.gov.lv/
(2) Cabinet of Ministers Regulation "Procedures for maintenance of the data management system, updating of data and circulation of information", 2014, https://likumi.lv/ta/id/266921-dabas-datu-parvaldibas-sistemas-uzturesanas-datu-aktualizacijas-un-informacijas-aprites-kartiba

indicators.justification:
Amendments to the law "On the Enterprise Register of the Republic of Latvia" (5) entered into force in 2020 and require publication of beneficial ownership data in open data format. Data are available for download on Latvia's Open Data portal (1) and contain information about beneficial owner's name, surname, part of national ID or month and year of birth, nationality, residence country, URI, legal entity registration number and date of registration. The website has a tool that allows users to filter data online. There is another data set (2) that is currently being uploaded and will be available according to BODS data standard. On December 1, 2020 Company Register stated (4) that they have received around 200 complaints from data users (mainly credit institutions) that beneficial ownership data do not match their findings after customer due diligence. 

(1)	Beneficial ownership dataset on the national (joint) open data portal, https://data.gov.lv/dati/lv/dataset/patiesie-labuma-guveji/resource/20a9b26d-d056-4dbb-ae18-9ff23c87bdee 
(2)	Beneficial ownership dataset according to BODS data standard, https://data.gov.lv/dati/lv/dataset/plg-bods/resource/19a7d5f5-5586-4de2-a710-fc7145a129f2
(4) Inese Helmane, LVportāls, "Krāpties un slēpties kļūst arvien grūtāk", 01.12.2020. https://lvportals.lv/viedokli/322413-krapties-un-slepties-klust-arvien-grutak-2020 
(5) Law "On the Enterprise Register of the Republic of Latvia", 1990. https://likumi.lv/ta/id/72847-par-latvijas-republikas-uznemumu-registru

indicators.justification:
The most detailed data on mortality (1) and births (2) are published by the Latvian Center for Disease Control and Prevention on their Health Statistics Database. The page and datasets have no reference to any version of the International Classification of Causes of Death or other standard and classification codes are not comparable. Different indicators are spread through several datasets. Additional information on birth data (e.g., regional coverage) is published by Latvia's Central Statistics Bureau on the Official statistics portal (3). All data are free of charge and available for download in machine-readable formats. 

(1) Data on mortality on Latvia's Health Statistics Database, https://statistika.spkc.gov.lv/pxweb/lv/Health/Health__Mirstiba/?tablelist=true
(2) Data on birth and pregnancy on Latvia's Health Statistics Database, https://statistika.spkc.gov.lv/pxweb/lv/Health/Health__Mates_berna_veseliba/?tablelist=true
(3) Birth data on Latvia's Official statistics portal: https://stat.gov.lv/lv/statistikas-temas/iedzivotaji/dzimstiba

indicators.justification:
Government agencies of Latvia publish information about queues for stationary services (1), queues for specialists, examinations, day hospital, rehabilitation, dental, services for children by days and regions (2), availability of Covid-19 vaccines by vaccination office, type of vaccine and date (3) and historical information about queues for outpatient services for 1st September 2019 (4). All data are available free of charge. Only two datasets are provided in open data machine-readable format. Data are updated once a month or once a week, and only the availability of Covid-19 vaccines displays the current real situation (updated once a week). Latvia's Open Government Partnership Action plan for 2020-2021 includes a commitment to open data on work of medical institutions and queues by services, work of doctors, distribution of funding, etc., in order to analyze and improve health sector governance, however, the commitment was assessed as only partly implemented in the first evaluation report from 2020 (5). 

(1) Queues for stationary services, website of the National Health Service, 12.07.2021., https://www.vmnvd.gov.lv/lv/stacionaro-pakalpojumu-gaidisanas-rindas
(2) Queues for specialists, examinations, day hospital, rehabilitation, dental, services for children by days and regions, demo version of National Health Service tool, 01.07.2021., http://rindapiearsta.lv/lv/mekle_isako
(3) Availability of Covid-19 vacines by vacination office, type of vacine and date, Ministry of Health of Latvia, 26.07.2021., https://www.vm.gov.lv/lv/jaunums/atbildes-uz-biezak-uzdotajiem-jautajumiem-par-vakcinaciju-pret-covid-19#ka-es-varu-noskaidrot-kada-veida-vakcinu-iespejams-sanemt-manis-izveletaja-vakcinacijas-punkta
(4)  Queues for outpatient services, joint open data portal, 27.09.2019., https://data.gov.lv/dati/lv/dataset/ambulatoro-pakalpojumu-gaidisanas-rindas/resource/e194b83d-a54e-4a9b-a50e-5f65064300f9
(5) State Chancellery of Latvia, 2021, "Latvia's Fourth National Open Government Plan 2020-2021: Mid-term evaluation of the implementation of the plan in 2020", page 11, https://www.mk.gov.lv/lv/media/8928/download

indicators.justification:
National Health Service of Latvia publish data on used Covid-19 vaccines as open data on the joint open data portal (1). Information is updated daily and can be accessed for the period from 04.12.2020. free of charge and in machine-readable format. Data include information about the type of the vaccine, name of the vaccination point, date of the vaccination and sex, age and special indication of the person. National Health Service also publish data on vaccine delivery to medical institutions and vaccination points free of charge and in machine-readable format as separate datasets once a week (2). There is also public information about numbers and types of vaccines delivered to Latvia (3) and what type of vaccines are available in the biggest vaccination points (4). 

(1)	Covid-19 vaccination dataset, National Health Service, 06.01.2021., https://data.gov.lv/dati/eng/dataset/covid19-vakcinacijas/resource/51725018-49f3-40d1-9280-2b13219e026f
(2)	Datasets on Covid-19 vaccine delivery to medical institutions, National Health Service, 09.04.2021., https://www.vmnvd.gov.lv/lv/vakcinacijas-iestadem-pieskirto-vakcinu-apjoms 
(3) Information on vaccines delivered to Latvia, National Health Service, 03.06.2021., https://www.vmnvd.gov.lv/lv/vakcinu-piegades
(4) Information on what type of vaccines are available in the biggest vaccination points, Ministry of Health of Latvia, 30.07.2021., https://www.vm.gov.lv/lv/jaunums/atbildes-uz-biezak-uzdotajiem-jautajumiem-par-vakcinaciju-pret-covid-19

indicators.justification:
There are two public registers where information on land tenure can be found - Land Register (1) and State Land Service (2). None of the registers are available in open data and relevant information is not free of charge. Some basic information is available free of charge: cadastre number or cadastral designation, name or address, cadastral value, base values, for real estate - whether it is registered in the land register, for land units and structures - the amount of the undivided notional part. Lursoft Ltd. also grants access to both registers through their website (3) for a fee, information is not in open data format. 
There are two datasets that are available in open data format: Confirmation requests (4) and  Purchase agreements (5).

(1)	Land Register of Latvia, https://www.zemesgramata.lv/saturs/lv/432-389-1
(2)	State Land Service of Latvia, https://www.kadastrs.lv/
(3)	Example of the Lursoft Ltd. analysis, https://www.lursoft.lv/uploads/zemesgramatas_izzinas_paraugs.png
(4)	Confirmation requests dataset, https://www.zemesgramata.lv/saturs/lv/170-169-1
(5)	Purchase agreements dataset, https://www.zemesgramata.lv/saturs/lv/189-169-1

indicators.justification:
Treasury and Ministry of Finance publish open datasets on State budget and its execution on different websites and they are available for download free of charge, in machine-readable format. Treasury publish general budget implementation reports each month and each quarter (1). Ministry of Finance publish consolidated State budgets together with additional documents and infographics (2). Treasury also publish several datasets on the joint open data portal: dataset on execution of the state budget by budget programs / sub-programs and classification codes (3) and execution of the state budget by institutions, budget programs / sub-programs and classification codes (5). Ministry of Finance publishes State budget datasets for years 2017-2021 with funding allocated to nine investment areas of state budget on the joint open data portal (4). 

(1) General budget implementation reports by Treasury, https://www.kase.gov.lv/parskati/kopbudzeta-izpildes-parskati

indicators.justification:
All declarations of interests and assets are available online through a dedicated portal on the website of the State Revenue Service [1]. The data contains information on incomes, assets, liabilities, as well as in-kind and non-financial interests. However, it does not contain details of assets and liabilities of family members, nor information on significant changes in assets and liabilities. The data does not contain unique identifiers public officials and family members. The website contains declarations filed by public officials since the year 2000, thus it allows to track changes over time. The data, which is available in Latvian (national language), is updated on a daily basis, meaning that new declarations get uploaded as soon as they are checked for accuracy. Data is available free of charge but is not openly licensed. All information on the State Revenue Service's website is subjected to copyright. The portal allows users to visualize declarations one by one, by inserting name and surname of the specific public officials. Other than that, there is no tool available to help users explore data (e.g., lists of public officials or search bars for specific data). Data is not provided in machine-readable format. As mentioned above, it is only possible to access individual records, and these are only available in HTML format. There is a prohibition to use any tool for automated extraction of the information without explicit consent from the State Revenue Service. There are no indications that the information is missing required data, not that the availability of this data has been affected by government response to COVID-19.

Sources

(1) Database of public officials' declaration in the website of the State Revenue Service - https://www6.vid.gov.lv/VAD

indicators.justification:
Data on political party financing is available on the website of the Corruption Prevention and Combating Bureau.[1] This includes details of donations, public funding, membership fees, in-kind and non-financial support, including first and last name of each donor [2], as well as details of parties' incomes, expenditures, assets, and liabilities [3], and public funding [4]. Apart from first and last name of the donor, only a semi-anonymised ID code representing the date is provided. As such, it can't be considered a unique identifier. The data do not include other specific information about donors, such as place of residence, occupation, and employer. Data is available free of charge but is not openly licensed. All information on the CPCB's website is subjected to copyright. The CPCB's website has an in-built tool that allows users to explore and filter the information. However, data is not provided in machine-readable format, nor it is possible to download the information in bulk. Data on political donations, gifts, membership fees and public funding is only available in HTML. Political parties' annual declarations and elections' declaration are available in PDF, as scanned documents. Data is available in the national language (Latvian) and, at the time of the assessment, content was being prepared for English and Russian language. Data on political donations and parties' declaration is available since 01/01/2002, while data on public funding is available since 01/01/2012. Data on donations, gifts and membership fees is updated in a timely manner (on a weekly basis), and political parties' annual declarations and those on elections are updated within 10 days after their submission. At the time of the assessment, the information was not missing any required data. There are no indications that the availability of this data has been affected by government response to COVID-19.

Sources
(1) Political Party Financing Database of the Corruption Prevention and Combating Bureau - https://www.knab.gov.lv/lv/partiju-finansu-datubaze

indicators.justification:
Data on public consultations can be found in the section "Public Participation" of the websites of individual institutions. In the case of the Executive branch of the government, the website of the Cabinet of Ministers and State Chancellery provides a directory of all such sections within individual Ministries' website, which can serve as examples [1]. The data include proposed and final regulations, as well as supporting information and related documents. While data on public participation processes do not always include full sets of comments, data on public consultations do. Overall, public institutions do not have a standard practice in structuring their "Public Participation" sections, which hinders both findability and assessment of data. Data on public consultations is available in Latvian language and free of charge. However, it is not openly licensed. Information on institution's website is subjected to copyright. While data on public institutions' website is updated as soon as new public consultations are announced or have ended, availability of historical data varies among different institutions. Overall, data is not provided in machine-readable format. While notices of intent are available in HTML format or as downloadable PDF, data on comments generated through public consultations is only available in PDF format. There are no indications that the information was required missing data, though assessment was made difficult by scattering of information across several different webpages and sections. There are no indications that the availability of this data has been affected by government response to COVID-19.

Sources
(1) Website of the State Chancellery and Cabinet of Ministers - https://www.mk.gov.lv/lv/noderigi-resursi

indicators.justification:
One of the goals of Latvia's Open Data Strategy (1) adopted in 2019 is to promote the development of data and technology-based innovations and their commercialization. However, the strategy has to be implemented without an additional budget, therefore no separate or new funding programs have been introduced. Alternatively, Activity No 5 of the implementation plan of the strategy (p.38) includes different existing business and innovation programs to potentially also fund initiatives that reuse open data. Government has cooperated with Latvian Open Technology Association in the organization of data hackathons for municipalities in 2019 (2) and schools in 2020 (3). In April 2021 the Ministry of Environmental Protection and Regional Development signed a memorandum of understanding with two universities in Latvia aiming at strengthening the role of universities in promoting data-based decision making, new products, technologies and services in Latvia (4).

indicators.justification:
The strategic approach to opening government data was set as one of Latvia's e-governance principles for years 2014-2020 and was formulated in "Information Society Development Guidelines 2014-2020" (1). In accordance with this policy, the national open data portal (2) was developed and launched in June 2017 and new data sets have since been published on regular basis. In total 520 data sets have been published by 87 institutions in 2021, mostly by national level institutions. In August 2019 the government approved an informative report "Open Data Strategy" (3) and has included open data initiatives in Latvia's Open Governance Partnership action plans for 2017-2019 (4) and 2020-2021 (5).

indicators.justification:
Political integrity datasets use a limited number of common identifiers and there is minimal consistency among them. Common identifiers include names of public officials, which are available across all three datasets (though only political financing data also includes a semi-anonymised ID code), as well as names of legal and natural persons associated with public officials in the interest and asset declarations, who might also have donated to political parties or participated in public consultations. Political integrity datasets share a limited number of common identifiers with relevant datasets in other themes. Data on Interest and asset declarations, public procurement and public consultations data share the name and registration number of companies associated with public officials, which might have won contracts from the institutions in which the officials work in.
Company information and political financing data share the name and semi-anonymised ID of company owners and members, who might have donated to political parties. Company information and interest and asset declarations share the name and registration number of legal entities associated with public officials as well as name of persons associated with them, including relatives, who might be beneficial owners or have positions in legal entities. Company information and data on public consultations share the name of the public official in charge of the process and names of legal entities participating in it.

indicators.justification:
According to Section 18.2., Part 1 of "Law on the Prevention of Money Laundering and Terrorism and Proliferation Financing" (1), from 1 December 2017 all legal persons, including partnerships, registered in Latvia's Company Register have to disclose their beneficial owners. Company Register has since published beneficial ownership data on their online register and with amendments to the Section 4.10. of the law "On the Enterprise Register of the Republic of Latvia" (2) from 1 November, 2020 this information is published also as open data. The definition of a beneficial owner is included in Section 1, Part 5 of the law "On the Enterprise Register of the Republic of Latvia" and includes persons who own more than 25 % of the shares or who directly or indirectly controls the legal person.

indicators.justification:
Article 96 of the Constitution of Latvia establishes the right to privacy (4). Given that the General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) delegated to all EU member states to develop national legislation, Latvia's parliament adopted a new law "Personal Data Processing Law" (1) that entered into force on July 5, 2018. The law contains provisions that are necessary to ensure the application of the Regulation therefore the scope of the law is the same as the scope of the GDPR (but it does not apply to intelligence agencies). Chapter II of the law specifies Data State Inspectorate as data supervisory authority within the meaning of the GDPR. Data State Inspectorate has published several guidelines and recommendations for citizens (2) on how to exercise their rights granted by law and together with the Ombudsman recommended the government to develop a regulatory framework for video surveillance (3) in 2020 but no amendments have been adopted. National law does not contain specific rules regarding Article 82 of the GDPR about the right to receive compensation in case of damage suffered. However, Section 1775 of the Latvian Civil Law (5) can be applied.

indicators.justification:
Section 4 of the Constitution of the Republic of Latvia (1) states that the Latvian language is the official language in the Republic of Latvia. Section 21, Part 1 of the Official Language Law (2) states that information provided for public information purposes by national and local level institutions and companies owned by state or local municipalities shall be provided only in the official language. There is no institution that has a clear obligation to ensure accurate and timely collection and publication of required data in Latvia. However, Section 40 of the Cabinet of Ministers' regulation "Procedures for Institutions to Post Information on the Internet" (3) states that if the data published in the government open data portal is found to be inconsistent with the definition of open data or other requirements stated in law, the Ministry of Environmental Protection and Regional Development of Latvia may make the data inaccessible for the public.

indicators.justification:
The definition of open data and the duty of institutions to post information in open data format is included in the Freedom of Information Law of Latvia (1) since 2015. The law is legally binding for all government and municipal authorities. The definition includes key elements of open data: free availability and no restrictions for re-use. Additionally, in 2020 the Government adopted new Procedures for Institutions to Post Information on the Internet that establish procedures for publishing open data (2). In August 2019 the Government adopted the first Latvian Open Data Strategy (3) with an action plan for 2019-2022 that includes quarterly capacity building and awareness raising events for government officials and private sector. The Government has published several documents/guidelines for open data publishers, including Metadata Description Standard (4).

Section 14, Part 1 of the law "On Budget and Financial Management" (1) states that information regarding the State budget shall be regularly published in a form that is fully comprehensive and the public can easily understand. And Cabinet of Ministers instruction "Instruction on the analysis of the state budget execution" (2) states how ministries should prepare information and analyse the budget expenses and submit it to the Ministry of Finance. But there are no guidelines for publishing payments of the State budget expenditure.

indicators.justification:
The Law on Prevention of Conflict of Interest (2002, last amended 2021) [1] mandates all Latvian public officials (Head of State, Ministers, Members of Parliament, and Civil Servants) to declare all the positions held in addition to that of public officials, income from outside employment, firm ownership, shares in public and private companies, real estate, movable assets, cash, debts and gifts that exceed the minimum wage, as well as participation in government contracts, as well as the name of spouses and family members. At the same time, the framework does not require collecting information on significant changes in assets and liabilities, nor disclosure of income and assets of family members.
The State Revenue Service collects declarations from all public officials, except those working in State security authorities, who have to submit the declaration to the Director of the Constitution Protection Bureau, and the Head of the Corruption Prevention and Combating Bureau, which together with the Director of the Constitution Protection Bureau must submit declarations to the Prime Minister or to his/her authorised person. These depository body also have to verify the accuracy of the submitted information, while the Corruption Prevention and Combating Bureau audits the information to identify violations of the law. Declarations of interest and assets must be made upon taking and leaving office and be updated annually. The Law mandates the State Revenue Service to make all declarations to be made publicly available online through a dedicated portal on its website. However, only those parts of the declarations which do not harm the protection of personal data are published. Regulation No. 478 of the Cabinet of Ministers (2002, amended 2016) [2] prescribes the procedures for the completion, submission, registration, and keeping of declarations. It also provides the template according to which officials have to submit the information, including publishable and non-publishable part. Thus, the regulation supports the collection of structured data. The framework requires declarations of the President, Members of the Parliament, Prime Minister, Deputy Prime Ministers, Ministers, Parliamentary Secretaries and city councillors to be published within one month after submission to the State Revenue Service, and declarations of all other public officials to be published within three months after submission to the State Revenue Service. However, the framework contains no provision for update of the content of the declaration submitted if some change occurs between different declaration periods.

Sources

(1) Law on the Prevention of Conflict of Interest in the Activities of Public Officials - https://likumi.lv/ta/en/en/id/61913-on-prevention-of-conflict-of-interest-in-activities-of-public-officials

(2) Regulation No. 478 of the Cabinet of Ministers - https://likumi.lv/ta/en/en/id/67750-procedure-for-completion-submission-registration-and-keeping-of-declarations-of-public-officials-and-for-drawing-up-and-submission-of-lists-of-persons-holding-the-office-of-a-public-official

indicators.justification:
At present, there are no laws, policies or regulations requiring the collection or publication of information on lobbying in Latvia. In September 2019, the Parliamentary Committee on Defence, Corruption and Internal Affairs set up a Working Group tasked with drafting regulation on lobbying [1], to be presented and voted by the Parliament by the end of the legislature in 2022. The Working Group includes representatives from different interest groups, including civil society, private sector and institutional counterparts. In January 2021, the Committee published a document [2] outlining number of basic principles that will serve as input for the draft law, expected to be made available for extensive public consultation in late 2021. Amongst others, relevant principles in the document include: i) a definition of "interest representative" that is broad enough to include all the main interest groups, including NGOs; and ii) a centralised register of interest representatives, where they would have to disclose their area of activity, clients, targets of lobbying and interactions with public decision-makers. As of May 2021, there was still lack of clarity with regard to the specific format and functionalities of the register, and whether information will be provided as open data. It is likely that these details will be defined upon potential adoption of the law through dedicated regulations.

Sources

(1) Webpage of the Parliament's Working Group on Lobbying - http://aizsardziba.saeima.lv/darba-grupa-lob%C4%93%C5%A1anas-atkl%C4%81t%C4%ABbas-likuma-izstr%C4%81dei

indicators.justification:
Political party financing in Latvia is regulated by the Law on Financing of Political Organisations (Parties) (1995, amended 2020) [1] as well as Regulation No. 417 and No.591 of the Cabinet of Ministers, which lay down specific provisions concerning the collection and publication of data on parties' finances [2][3]. The Pre-Election Campaign Law (2012, amended 2021) lays down additional provision concerning campaign activities of parties, candidates and third parties [4]. The framework covers all political parties active in the national territory and running for national, local and European elections. The Law on Financing of Political Parties requires political parties to prepare and submit annual reports with information on their assets, liabilities, income and spending as well as declarations of income and expenses of electoral campaigns. The framework also mandates political parties to record and report information on financial contributions, in-kind and non-financial support, and disclose the identity of the donors. Corporate donations are banned. The Law on Pre-Election Campaigns provides clear definitions of campaigning activities, candidates and third parties. Pre-election incomes and expenses of candidates are considered as expenses of the party and accounted in the relevant election declarations. The Corruption Prevention and Combating Bureau (CPCB) is the public body in charge of the collection and publication of the data. The framework requires a verification process from the CPCB, which has to carry out audits on annual declarations within 4 months after submission and inspect declaration of electoral incomes and expenditures within one month after the election has taken place. In addition, the CPCB must examine the conformity of donations, gifts and membership fees within 45 days after they have been reported and carry out additional examinations in cases of irregularities. The framework mandates the CPCB to publish on its website annual reports and election statements no later than 10 days after their submission, and information on donations, gifts and membership fees no later than 7 days after they have been reported. Regulations No. 417 and No. 591 lay down provisions for the specific data points to be reported by political parties when submitting information on their finances. For membership fees, gifts and donations these include name of the donors and political parties, type and value of donations and date. As such, the framework supports the collection of structured data.

Sources

indicators.justification:
The Cabinet of Minister's Regulation No. 970 "Procedures for Public Participation in the Development Planning Process" (2009) [1] prescribes the procedures for the public participation in the development planning process of the Parliament, Cabinet of Ministers, subordinated and independent State Institutions, planning regions, and local governments, thus providing national coverage. This includes provisions for the collection and publication of information on public consultations. This includes publication of notice of intent, proposed regulations, full sets of comments and challenges generated through the process (including responses). There is no central agency in charge of collection and publication of data on public consultations in a single location. These duties are assigned to individual institutions, which upon organising public consultations have to appoint a public official with the duty to ensure collection and public access to the documents to be discussed on the website throughout the process. Responsible officials have to post notifications no later than 14 days before submitting the document to the decision-making body, and to publish summary of public consultations within 30 days after they have ended. The framework does not contain specific requirements on verification processes. Annex I and II of the regulation provide templates according to which all information on public consultations should be published. Data on notice of intents must contain all relevant details concerning the law, the modality of the public consultation, timeline for submissions of comments and opinions, appointed public official and other details. Data on summary of public consultation must contain name of the legal person who submitted a proposal or objection, essence of the proposal/objection, whether it was considered or not, as well as justification for the decision made on it. Thus, the framework supports the collection of structured data.

Sources

indicators.justification:
The Freedom of Information Law (1998, last amended 2015) [1] lays down provisions for public access to information generated and held by all public institutions in. Exemptions to disclosure are outlined in the Law, as well as in the Law on Official Secrets (1996) and Personal Data Protection Law. The framework covers all institutions in the three branches of government and public administrations. It contains provisions for access to specific documents subject to reactive and proactive disclosure, including draft legal instruments, enacted legal instruments, annual budgets, annual chart of accounts and annual report and programmes of public entities. It also specifies procedures for access to the information, deadlines for its release, as well as exemptions and overrides. However, there is no enforcement or oversight body tasked with managing implementation of the law or collecting and publishing statistics on RTI performance. Moreover, there is no public interest test whereby exemptions to disclosure may be overridden for the benefit of the public, no appeal process through independent non-judicial mechanism (e.g., information commissioner), nor sanctions for violations of FOI provisions.

Sources

(1) Freedom of Information Law - https://likumi.lv/ta/en/en/id/50601-freedom-of-information-law

indicators.justification:
Lursoft Ltd. is an IT company registered in Latvia and the only relevant provider of services based on data from the Register of Enterprises of Latvia. Their products include analytical services, monitoring, B2B, and other solutions that enable legal entities and individuals to better evaluate their customers that are registered in Latvia. Users have to pay a fee to access most of the services. Investigative journalists sometimes publish relationship graphs generated by Lursoft (1).

(1)	About Lursoft Ltd., website of Lursoft. https://www.lursoft.lv/en/about-lursoft

indicators.justification:
There are a number of cases of civil society and media using political integrity data, particularly political financing data and interest declarations, for accountability purposes. There are also isolated cases of scholars and private sector using this data, though the purpose is limited to academic research and promotion of services rather than accountability as such. Civil society organisations and activists have mostly used data on political financing and interest and asset declarations, in conjunction with on company ownership and public procurement, to develop web platforms, tools, and apps, allowing users to easily explore data and detect political corruption, conflict of interest and other irregularities. Recent relevant examples include the platform "Deputāti uz Delnas by Transparency International Latvia [1], the web app "Opener" [2], by Transparency International Estonia and Transparency International Latvia, as well as a web app developed by a data activist that allows users to explore in detail the private interests of candidates through network visualisations [3]. Media in Latvia have mostly used data on political financing and interest and asset declarations to expose irregularities in public officials' conduct, to verify potential conflict of interest in their decisions, and to ascertain whether public officials' declared wealth and possessions corresponded to reality. In a number of cases, media have used the data to raise public awareness about newly elected or appointed top-level officials. In other cases, they have used the data to corroborate findings from law enforcement or journalist investigations.[4][5] It is difficult to identify a direct causal link between specific civil society initiatives or media reports using data on political integrity and measures taken by the government as a result. However, it might be argued that their consistent use by journalists to identify corruption and bad governance, as well as their employment by civil society to enhance public scrutiny, have contributed to keep a high public awareness about the ever-present corruption risks in Latvia's politics as well as relevant issues in the current availability and quality of data. Over time, this has prompted the government to strengthen measures in relevant political integrity areas. For example, in 2019 the legislation on political party financing was amended to increase six-fold the amount of public financing to political parties in order to reduce political parties' dependence on private actors to carry out their activities. In 2019, the law on Conflict of Interest was also amended to prohibit MPs to take up paid positions in civil society organisations and foundations, reportedly to prevent that their private interests in those organisations would influence their public decision-making.

Sources

(1) Website "Deputāti uz Delnas" - https://www.deputatiuzdelnas.lv/
(2) Website "Opener" - https://opener.ee/
(3) Website - App to monitor interests of candidates to Latvia's local elections - https://aivisb.shinyapps.io/202103_PV2021/
(4) Media Article - LSM.lv "Magazine IR: OIK businessmen have donated 1.3 million euros to the parties" - https://www.lsm.lv/raksts/zinas/latvija/zurnals-oik-biznesmeni-partijam-ziedojusi-13-miljonus-eiro.a323804/
(5) Media Article - Delfi.lv "Vespa, debts and loans - What the declarations of the Riga City Executive show" - https://www.delfi.lv/news/national/politics/vespa-paradi-un-aizdevumi-ko-rigas-domes-vadiba-uzrada-savas-deklaracijas.d?id=53352015

indicators.justification:
Public procurement data in Latvia are used by government and non-governmental organizations in different tools. Public Procurement Bureau of Latvia has developed a procurement data visualization tool (1), has published a compilation of procurement data analysis (2), has developed a red flag system on the government page where public procurement notices are published (3). Two non-governmental organizations from Latvia (Transparency International Latvia and Data School) together with partners in Estonia have developed a demo version for an interactive tool "Opener" that filters public procurement for
single bidder procurements with brief bidding periods and contracts won before or after political donations (4). (For this tool data for Latvia's public procurements are taken from Opentender rather than Public Procurement Bureau.) There are several indications that government and non-governmental organizations use procurement data for policy making and awareness raising. 

(1) Public procurement data visualization tool, Procurement Monitoring Bureau. https://info.iub.gov.lv/lv/visual
(2) Procurement data analysis, Procurement Monitoring Bureau. https://www.iub.gov.lv/lv/aktualie-iepirkumu-dati
(3) A red flag system on public procurement online system, Procurement Monitoring Bureau. https://info.iub.gov.lv/lv/meklet/cpv/33190000-8/
(4) Demo version of Opener. https://opener.ee/procurements
